questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated, on probation, or parole for a felony of moral turpitude?
questions.extra: The phrase “moral turpitude” describes an offense or crime that is vile or an insult to morality. Such a crime typically involves fraud, dishonesty, or anything that goes against the norms of society.

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include:
  • Murder
  • Manslaughter
  • Assault
  • Sexual assault
  • Sexual abuse of a minor
  • Robbery
  • Arson
  • Burglary
  • Theft
  • Forgery
  • Endangering the welfare of a minor
  • Riot
  • Criminal mischef
  • Misconduct involving a controlled substance
  • Distribution or possession of child pornography
NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

In Alaska, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Have you been convicted of a felony of moral turpitude?
questions.extra:
The phrase “moral turpitude” describes an offense or crime that is vile or an insult to morality. Such a crime typically involves fraud, dishonesty, or anything that goes against the norms of society. Common felonies of moral turpitude include:
  • Murder
  • Manslaughter
  • Assault
  • Sexual assault
  • Sexual abuse of a minor
  • Robbery
  • Arson
  • Burglary
  • Theft
  • Forgery
  • Endangering the welfare of a minor
  • Riot
  • Criminal mischef
  • Misconduct involving a controlled substance
  • Distribution or possession of child pornography
NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

options.result: Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now.

options.result:

For assistance, contact the Restore Your Vote hotline by calling (202) 857-0314 or (888) 306-8683 (toll-free) or emailing:

RestoreYourVote@campaignlegal.org.

questions.value: Have you ever been charged or convicted of a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result:
In Mississippi, you are eligible to vote.

Only individuals convicted of one of 23 specific felony crimes lose the right to vote (arson; armed robbery; bigamy; bribery; embezzlement; extortion; felony bad check; felony shoplifting; forgery; larceny; murder; obtaining money or goods under false pretense; perjury; rape; receiving stolen property; robbery; theft; timber larceny; unlawful taking of motor vehicle; statutory rape; carjacking; and larceny under lease or rental agreement.)

Register to vote now

questions.value: Were you convicted of homicide?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now.

Restore your rights

questions.value: Are you currently on probation or parole for one of the 23 barred crimes?

options.result: Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Your right to vote can only be granted through a bill passed by both houses of the legislature or through the Governor.

In Mississippi, you are eligible to vote as long as you are not incarcerated for a felony or misdemeanor.

Only individuals convicted of one of 23 specific felony crimes lose the right to vote (arson; armed robbery; bigamy; bribery; embezzlement; extortion; felony bad check; felony shoplifting; forgery; larceny; murder; obtaining money or goods under false pretense; perjury; rape; receiving stolen property; robbery; theft; timber larceny; unlawful taking of motor vehicle; statutory rape; carjacking; and larceny under lease or rental agreement.)

questions.value: Were you convicted between 1973 and 1981?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole. The phrase “moral turpitude” describes an offense or crime that is vile or an insult to morality. Such a crime typically involves fraud, dishonesty, or anything that goes against the norms of society.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include: murder, manslaughter, assault, sexual assault, sexual abuse of a minor, robery, arson, burglary, theft, forgery, endangering the welfare of a minor, riot, criminal mischef, misconduct involving a controlled substance, and distribution or possession of child pornography.

NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

options.result: Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now.

questions.value: Have you completed your sentence for a violent felony, including probation or parole?

options.result:
In Wyoming, people with violent felony convictions are permanently disenfranchised unless they appeal to the governor after a waiting period (5 years for restoration, 10 years for a pardon).

Please apply to your Governor for voting rights restoration.
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now.

In Wyoming, you are eligible to vote.
